page.title: 17BROTHERTON WOODS
page.content: The wood occupies a valley covering 10 acres. It is over 10,000 years old, dating back to the Ice Age. This makes it the oldest woodland on Merseyside. It grows on a gradient which makes it unsuitable for agriculture. Its base is Boulder Clay and Triassic Sandstone. Important for the survival of different varieties of flora and fauna, the woods shelter badgers, foxes, and has suitable habitat for rarer plants such as primrose, twayblade, and small_leaved lime.More common varieties are wood anemone, wood sorrel and bluebell. Trees include sycamore, hornbeam, wych elm and oak: these supply the birdlife with a nesting habitat. Rarer migrants include blackcap, willow warbler, chiff_chaff, kingfisher, fieldfare. The woods are protected and used as a leisure facility.
